044417.question: Hi Bill. So I've got a pretty good relative pitch. Once I know the note of one pitch, I can pretty much tell the rest because I have a reference. But I want to tell a pitch without a reference. Can you teach me how to do that? I know perfect pitch is not the most important thing in the world but I just want to know if it's possible to learn. I want to identify notes without reference.
044417.answer: yes you can't get really hard wired for absolute pitch unless you do it before you are about 6 years old the good news is, it's not that hard to do, you just won't be as fast as those who are super hard wired AP. who knows, you may even catch some in a lie ...... but anyway, start by memorizing the key of every song you know, and every common beep and tone in your society. (microwaves, car horns, your electronic devices, etc. just get to know them all. you probably won't forget). based on your early childhood experience, you may find that you have at least one note absolutized in your memory. and you can learn to work with that quite easily, although 12 times slower than someone who had all 12 absolutized from childhood. i've actually never met anyone who has that, and i've never heard of anyone having that while also being really good and comfortable with everything musical / relativity has to offer. i trust that it's possible but haven't seen it yet. which is somewhat re-assuring to those of us who forgot to learn in any key other than C until age ........ 7

044465.question: Do improvised 'chord substitutions' work in a band setting? 044479.question: Would you say that a lot of your answers on this page agree with this philosophy, particularly ones about breaking rules and "what is meaningful in the universe? you"? "Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light, not our darkness that most frightens us. We ask ourselves, 'Who am I to be brilliant, gorgeous, talented, fabulous?' Actually, who are you not to be? You are a child of the universe. Your playing small does not serve the world. There is nothing enlightened about shrinking so that other people won't feel insecure around you. We are all meant to shine, as children do. We were born to make manifest the glory that is within us. It's not just in some of us; it's in everyone. And as we let our own light shine, we unconsciously give other people permission to do the same. As we are liberated from our own fear, our presence automatically liberates others." ~Mariann e Williamson

044526.question: Do you ever think about having mainstream success with one of your music, like having one of your songs 'on the charts'? Would you ever write a song with the specific intention of trying to make a pop song or do you think it's best to stay true to yourself and make your music how you like it? Sorry if that came off sounding rude, I know you've already had a lot of success with your stuff and have lots of devoted fans. I've probably listened to your music more than any other artist in the past year or so.. but I'd like to see you selling out madison square garden and hearing your songs whenever I turn on the radio, etc. I think there's a lot of pop artists who actively try to make 'pop music'.. which isn't to say that pop can't still be unique or great or whatever, but I think there's more to writing pop than just making what you like. I think a lot of these artists are really good at looking at trends in music and knowing how to appeal to a wide audi ence and all that stuff.
044526.answer: always all of them, if possible every time every time trends don't grow on trees... someone has to make the trends!

044592.question: I feel Slow Down talks about that feeling of pressure when a deadline is coming. And not even a proper deadline, maybe some deadline you have inside your head, like "i'm good enough, I should be able to finish this by tomorrow". That sort of feeling. You should slow down and take of yourself, stop and think what you really feel and what you really want to do. Is this the case with the song? Towards the end I got the feeling of doing something because someone asked. In this case, writing a song about how that special someone is always there for you, in this case the "special someone" is the client, and we could easil interpret the client as the audience who pay to listen to music. Is this how you feel about the music business? I apologise for the amount of questions, I just feel you're really authentic but the lack of wanting to explicitly tell what you're feeling is keeping me from really understand where you're coming from. But the thing with music is that... that's alright. It's not always about understanding. Sometimes you just gotta think and deduct. And that is what I'm doing right now. So it's fun, in a certain way, and I hope you're having fun with this question. I just wish you the best because you've always kept yourself honest and fought throughout the uncomfortableness. Love to you and your loved ones.
044592.answer: no not quite that is what keeps you hopefully coming back for more

044596.question: was the way you made the song feel like the song starts 1.5 times faster than it actually is a subconscious way to get us to feel like the song's already slowed down? also what in the world would you even parse that intro in? like 5 quarter note triplets, so you might even write it as 5/6, irrationally? come on
044596.answer: possibly it would have to be a completely different tempo than the rest of the song. it doesn't line up with anything. when i was recording other parts for the verse, after the pre-intro was done, i really had to turn the click on and completely ignore the pre-intro. i can tell you it does not line up properly unless you call it a tempo change on paper. actually there is a further complication because after it ends there's still 1 swung 16th note going into the next part, because the landing point is essentially the "a" of 4 so to speak

044620.question: Hey bill, loved the new song. There were definitely bits that sounded similar to long long long journey and it felt a lot less structured. Did you do this on purpose? Nevertheless, thanks for making it :)

044628.question: Hello, do you have any advice for learning different keys for piano (A, Bb, etc...) I am pretty much self taught, but i struggle with learning keys.
044628.answer: you'll have to take some songs you know already and then play them in the next key. if it's in C, and you know it in C, try learning it in F. if you are having trouble figuring out what key the song you know is in, ..... try very simple songs ? like the alphabet song for example, if you play that in C the first 2 notes are C. that would be in the key of C. that doesn't mean every song starts on the note of the key it's in, but some songs do .... i think you should start by learning a lot of simple songs in the key of C. i think you will get used to it ... it's kind of like learning which wall of a room is the floor ... there's no rule but you can usually get a feel for it. then once you know a bunch of songs in C then start learning all those songs in F. it should look exactly the same except you will have to swap in 1 black note to make it sound right. get used to that and then you can go to the next key (Bb) in which you will have to swap in 1 more black note. or, go backwards, back to C, then go the other way to the next key (G), in which case you will have to swap in a a different black note the other way. if you go through the keys this way (C, F, Bb, Eb) it will be only 1 slight twist each time and you should learn it fine. or going the other direction it's C, G, D, A, etc

044714.question: What do you think about when you write your notes?

044715.question: Been listening to a lot of joni mitchell lately, and I've been really inspired by her guitar parts... particularly how she uses so many alternate tunings to get some cool fresh chord voicings.. I know you're not really a guiarist, but my question is, do you think that there's any way to figure out what tuning is being used just by listening to a song? I was thinking that the tonic chord provides a big clue. You wouldnt tune to open D, but then play in the key of G# or something (if you're in open D, your 1chord will probably be D). But once you throw in capos to the mix the tonic chord clue isn't very helpful (you can tune to open D, but then put your capo on the 2nd fret to play in E, etc)... Also, side question, how does using a lot of different tunings work live? Like were 50% of joni mitchell concerts just her tuning her guitar a million times?
044715.answer: it's kind of like a murder mystery. you just gotta study the clues and you might figure it out, or you might not in which case the murderer will go free multiple guitars. depending on your income bracket you may even have a person hand them to you and take away the previous one

044716.question: You seem to be in a bit of a major key overload, also a starting-sections-with-the-one chord overload. I dare you to record a song that doesn't use the major one as the first chord of the A or B section. I don't think you've done that since "what's going on". Just an idea..love your songs, just a friendly dare..a minor song with like a hip-hoppy beat would be amazing from you I think. But don't worry, I'm just a creatively stifled dude who is bitter because I don't have the guts or focus to put myself out there or work hard on my own music, so I critique other people's music to feel better about myself. Hope you have a great day and happy songwriting!!
044716.answer: minor songs always seem like a good idea in thought but then when it comes time for the magic, they have a habit of swapping themself out. for example, 'outside' verse (just picked up the newspaper) originally came to me with the first chord as it's relative minor. same melody but the first chord as it's rel. minor. that was how it went (so then it would have been C#-7, F#-7, B7sus4) but then as i familiarized myself with the figure and started writing more lines, they automatically felt better starting from the rel 1 (E). speaking of outside, the chorus starts on 5 (and also the intro). it seems like a nice idea, in theory, to be sad sometimes, but in reality there is never a great time to do it long journey chorus starts on 4. every bridge or B section of every song starts on non-1 i almost never use the 1 chord to start the B sec

044717.question: I am at music school, I am a drummer and want to compose music, i have some moderate to intense internal struggles. you are very inspiring to me
044717.answer: there are some crazy twists and turns you probably will and should go through. if you do a good job sort of documenting where things are at each day that will help you maintain clear focus. and when all is said and done i think your drumming foundation will give you some outrageous advantages especially when it comes to the world of time. even if you become an actor, or sports announcer, anything, you'll still see those time-related advantages. and don't forget to leave school and get lost in the jungle

044739.question: Why does "slow down" seem louder than your other songs? Also, sometimes it feels like the vocals aren't really clear, and are being covered up by the other instruments. Or the lyrics just don't feel heavy enough, there's a lot of breath and air. So it sounds unbalanced some of the times I listen to it.
044739.answer: perhaps because i was informed the loudness war was over a few months ago but then someone recently told me it is not entirely, and they said my songs seem to be quieter than everyone else's. so i was sure to give an extra push. someone also said the highs were too weak, which i figured was true. someone also said the bass was weak, so i tried to run the bass a little louder. someone also said the bass was still weak after i did that. sometimes i find it easier to quickly compensate for an unclear instrumental mix by simply bringing the vocals louder. but that's not entirely fair because that makes the groove weaker. so with this one i may have kept the insts stronger. also i think i was still aware that the highs were still not strong enough so i likely boosted the highs. also, too much mids are also always a problem so i almost always tuck the heck out of that otherwise it is just extremely volatile all the time unless i spend years micro managing it. which i assume no one has time to do. would you like to mix my songs for me, i'm looking for someone who has the level of professional experience needed to really do it properly, on a professional time schedule, and it sounds like you might be that person. can you give me some examples of tracks you have mixed

044758.question: How do you imagine performing your tunes live? I'm listening to 'long long journey' right now and the sound effects, backing vocals and all of the different keyboard sounds would be epic to see live.
044758.answer: with a band it wouldn't be that way at all live. it would hopefully be much better and more well rounded in sound. any song can be done any way, that's one of the most fun things about songs. and i exploit this to the fullest by never doubting that i can do any song all by myself, using only the tools i have. despite the fact that it usually sounds drastically different than i may have imagined it. a great majority of my songs would probably be much better as guitar songs of some sort. but that's just not what i can do nor have. when the live band show comes around, it will open up many many different doors so that a lot of the shenanigans i do on records will not be necessary anymore... this is why it seems strange to me when i hear people cover my songs and they cover every little riff in between lyrics excactly the way my recording did. to me that wasn't even part of the song, that's just the best way i could think of to deliver the song at that time using the only tools i have available. for example i bend over backwards doing all kinds of things to make up for the fact that i can never really have a strumming guitar. a strumming guitar of some sort is what every song probably really needs. and yet because i don't have that i usually end up doing completely different and unrelated things, to compensate. which i think has worked surprisingly well unless you ask the haters and hatresses

044769.question: I realized yesterday that to deal with my negative emotions, I should let them run wild and put that anger towards something rather than keep them locked inside. Doing this is great because the next time I'm confronted with the thing that may scare me or upset me, it won't frighten me or shake me up. Instead, my emotions will be way more manageable and I'll probably be more comfortable with them since I acknowledge them and express them so much, rather than avoiding them and letting them have a negative affect on me.

044774.question: Can you give me any tips on how to hear and distinguish a fully diminished chord from a half diminished chord? Do you instantly know what it is or do you have to actively concentrate to the 7th? Also, why is it so difficult for me to distinguish a diminished triad from an augmented triad? It really shouldn't be, they're way too different and yet I have a hard time doing it. I can tell the difference between these chords if I try really hard to isolate pitches but I want to be able to instantly hear and know what it is, just like I can instantly distinguish a major from a minor chord. Do you have any advice? Many thanks
044774.answer: yes one thing to remember with 'diminished' chords is, the way they work is upside down. once you get that it starts to make more sense. so when you say the '7th', it actually doesn't really feel or sound like a 7th of anything. let me give you some examples... key of C. first chord C. second chord, just move the bass note up 1, and keep the other notes, so it's C#, E, G. that's C#dim. so it's like C but with the C note moved up. and the chord actually behaves almost just like A7. so a lot of songs may start C, C#dim, when actually it is a very close sister of C, A7. you'll notice this in a lot of songs, especially from the 1930s or 40s. On the subject of the "diminished 7" well that sounds pretty much the same. it's just a continuation of the diminished thing, it's all stacked 3rds, a very dizzy sound. and again to use the previous example, it would be like C7, then if you move the C note up and keep the rest the same that is just like C#dim7. and again, it's like a substitute for A7b9. wants to go to Dmin in both cases, and most often will. C, C#dim, Dmin. .... but the other one you asked about, half-dim, (or some people call it min7b5) again the 7th won't really feel like a 7th of anything, because diminished chords don't really sit on their feet, they hang from above, as i'm trying to explain, so actually generally what i would say is, a half-dim chord is gonna sound like a minor triad with a certain note in the bass. let's say, Fmin with D in the bass. that's what it sounds like. let's go to the key of Cmin, and let's say you have Fmin, G7, Cmin. if you take that chord sequence, and listen closely, and plug the headphones into your smartphone, you will notice secretly there might be a D bass note under that Fmin. that makes it Dmin7b5 (or D half-dim) instead. the names of these chords are kind of misleading and don't particularly feel like good names for them but that's just the names that are used. probably less so nowadays because this kind of literacy has fallen somewhat out of style .... but the example i just mentioned is generally the most common way you will hear those chords used. the main thing to remember here is that diminished chords mostly mostly mostly usually nearly always do NOT stand on their own and are not used on their own. so if you start to think too much about the chord individually it will not seem to make sense. yet it occurs very normally and commonly as part of a sequence. so the best thing you can do is just look at where it occurs in songs, and just become accustomed to those patterns. and then you will recognize the pattern. and when you hear that Dhalf-dim, G7, Cmin, you will instantly know it is either that OR Fmin, G7, Cmin. but you will have to plug in the headphones and listen close to see if that D bass note is there, to know for sure which it is. but you were asking about the difference between Ddim and Dhalf-dim, well i would say that those 2 aren't the ones you wanna tell the difference between, they're not really even that closely related. i'd say it's more about telling the difference between Dhalf-dim and Fmin. and the difference between Ddim and Bb7. and in both cases you would need to turn up the bass to hear the difference but there is not that much difference. the way you would tell the difference between Ddim and Dhalf-dim is just that they are used in different parts of the song. it's kind of like a wrench and a broom. you can usually tell which one is which because they are mostly not even used in the same context. but the biggest thing i can say, again, is just look at the songs and just find out what happens in songs they have a similar dizzying effect because you are stacking 2 minor 3rds or 2 major thirds in a row, pushing it out of key i hope you are doing this from inside a song and not outside. because dim and aug chords in particular are very much out of context if they are used outside of a song. and with aug, it's almost like borderline it's almost unfair that that one even has a name. because when you get into that territory it's like you're doing a song and you just need to change one note a certain way and you do it. and there might not really be a name for the chord. usually you don't just go around playing augmented chords .... the fact that it has a name make it seem like more of a solid/usable thing than it really is. in other words, the places it is used almost always seems like a sort of exception of some kind. there are many other patterns of notes that are sort of built out of all wholetones, etc, which are a complete mess to try to name. and i feel that a straight up augmented triad is in that family and is kind of unfair that that one gets such an easy name. and i've seen a lot of people get distracted early on trying to learn what it means and what its importance is, just because it gets brought up early in classes along with minor and major chords. but really it's something that should be discovered through songs, as needed. along with all the other things which may not have names

044791.question: Why can't you have a strumming guitar?
044791.answer: i can, but recording a guitar would break a boundary that i have thus far never broken. it's not that i couldn't break it, but i have always been vastly able to accomplish everything i've needed without breaking that boundary. it's kind of like when you are writing essays for school and you are typing all of them. you are typing and typing and typing and typing and typing, and then you want some different fonts so you change the font and that's cool and good. and then you get to a part where you might actually need to write it on paper with an actual quill and ink. you may have a quill in the closet and you think it works and you think you know how to use it maybe .... but do you have paper? maybe/maybe not ... but they sell paper at the store and you think you could probably get the paper .... but what will really happen if you put the quill on to that paper? will there be any unexpected twists and challenges? also you have to get the image back into the computer somehow. ... and you might have a scanner but you are not sure if it works ... and then you will have to make sure it is integrated into your digital work in a way that feels right and makes sense. But you have never gotten around to think about any of this because you have learned to get absolutely everything done by using fonts in innovative ways. so as i said it's an entirely different door which i have avoided opening for a long time, and many people used to lecture me in the past about how i could never succeed without opening that door. but i never listened to them and i never opened the door, because i have always felt that i have had huge advantages otherwise. but i am now for the first time actually considering doing it. i only started considering this about 3 days ago but i'm really starting to think it might be a good idea. getting really sick of that fake banjo

045059.question: Hmmm is there any particular reason why some people use Cb to refer to B or E# to refer to F? Coz I've seen this in a couple places (mainly Synthesia)
045059.answer: it's not some people, it's some situations. if you are in the key of Gb, there is the B note but if you call it B then you have Gb, Ab, Bb, B, Db, Eb. this gets real messy if you try to put it on the staff. to use a key signature on a staff you just flat everything you need and then play the scale, with all the letters laid out. so you can't have 2 B notes, you'd have to keep flatting and sharping it. the same would be true for E#, which would be the last note the key of F# major. if you called if F it would be a mess when you write on the staff, you'd have to keep sharping and unsharping the F

045186.question: So I've noticed myself having really specific problems with making content. A lot of times I'll feel anxious during the day and that's when I most want to make stuff, and I think of all these great ideas during times like class, but then afterward, when I actually have the opportunity to work, I'm so relieved and relaxed by the day being over that I can't call up the same emotions that I had during the day and therefore can't create anything genuine. Is this a problem you had to deal with at all, and if it was, is the solution to just wait until you're in a position where you make your own schedule, or is it something else? thanks
045186.answer: you'll need to learn to write down / save the ideas you have when you are away from the studio. this is where most of your best ideas might start. so you'll want to get good at catching them. nowadays almost any phone has more than enough capability to do this. just sing a quick demo and explain everything you need to know about the idea, and then when you get home add it to the list with a reference to the audio file / note

045194.question: I absolutely love the new song. I'm very curious about the time signature when you sing "ba da dee da da dee do". How would that be notated? Did you change from 4/4 to 7/8? It sounds so fascinating. Please enlighten me!
045194.answer: it's all in 4 but it kind of pretends to be in 3 over the course of the same bar length. so triplets would probably do the trick. you could do &a1 a2e 3, (that's rigidly 16ths) or you could do &a1 let2trip 3 (using mostly triplets). in reality it's probably stretched somewhere in between those 2, but the time signature does not change

045222.answer: just listened to the entire first verse and it's not there. just listened to the second verse and it's not there either. just listened to the entire bridge, it's not there. here's another verse, i doubt it will be here because all the verses are the same. seems it's not in the entire AABA, ... the song is long so i'm skipping through these verses cuz they seem to be all the same ... another bridge, ... whole song seems to be just these 2 sections, .... anything maj7#11 is virtually nowhere. ah, the second to last chord of the song uses it, not in the verse/bridge etc but just to end it. yes, that is where it usually makes sense, on a b2 chord. actually my first draft of the ending of 'long long long journey' used it this way, right before the end. i can't remember if i said this before but the main place that chord normally seems to work is on b2 chords, which makes sense because the 1 and 5 notes of the key would be those 2 notes it is supposed to have. commonly used on guitar in the key of E, you'd hear F with the high E and B strings still ringing.

045286.question: Hello Bill. The universe is so humongous big. And it's basically empty. So nothing that we do really matters. And yet it does. Because we are a small spark of self-consciousness in what appears to be a never-ending expanse of lifelessness. There is all of this stuff here, but it's so far apart in all of this nothingness. It doesn't matter, because we are so small, and yet it's the only thing that matters because we the planets are all that really exist. Going around stars that give us heat and energy and life and brought us into this world and keep us safe in their gravity wells. This solar system is our playground and we're both spoiling and squandering it. So many beautiful worlds that we could get to know. The things we aren't doing could save us from our eventual demise, and the things that we are doing are speeding it up. We are trapped on this planet by our own ineptitude and our own inability to just be cool to one another and try to think ab out how cool the universe is. That's why I like you. You make music that's chill and gets people thinking about how cool shit is. I want to help make more people think about the universe before it's too late because they've just been thinking about themselves. I feel lost and confused and don't know how to start. I tried some stuff but it just got me in trouble and I lost my job because apparently music isn't professional and shouldn't be shared over work email. A lot of other shit happened too. Now I'm broken and tired and just want to run away to the wilderness but it doesn't exist anymore, especially not in the polluted and soon-to-be-underwater concrete hellscape that is Florida. I'm lost and confused and finding hope in your music even though I hate what trying to follow in your footsteps has done to my life. I just wanna run away from the bad. I just wanna run towards the good. I just wanna run. And yet all I can seem to do is cry for the mistakes we as a living planet have ma de and t he things we have done to ourself. I love this universe. I hate this universe. It's fascinating and brilliant. It's horrible and cruel. It has so much potential and so much risk. I just want to help it. And yet I feel so incapable of doing so. Can we please just start to be a real planet with real goals and dreams and impressive accomplishments instead of a ball of fighting jerks that will destroy itself? I don't know what to do anymore.
045286.answer: we are getting there and have been getting there for a long time. we have made crazy progress. i did some world history research and found out we all used to be rocks for an extremely long time. then some how we discovered, 1 bit at a time, how to have more fun. and each discovery is faster and wilder than the previous

045301.question: I'm a little confused by how to say a rhythm. So apparently you can count 16th notes in a 4/4 by saying "1 e & uh 2 e & uh 3 e & uh 4 e & uh". Is that standardized? So if I say that, everyone will understand that e.g. the "e" syllable is before the "&"? I've seen a couple questions and answers on here that seem to use this kind of notation. Also, how do you count odd time signatures that way? Do they have standardized ways of saying them as well? How does it all work?
045301.answer: i'd say so. it's spelled 1 e & a yes, it's also like an address for when a note is. if you say a note is "on the and of 4" that means it's the last 8th note of the bar. if you say something is "on the a of 2" that would be the second 16th note in the second beat, in other words the 6th 16th note of the bar would be the same probably, unless it's like 6/8 or 9/8 or 12/8 etc, which by convention are usually based in groups of 3 8th notes. less so

045419.question: hi bill, i play the keys, and i'll eventually play with a band or other people, but i'm not sure how this accompaniment thing works. what i do right now is listen my favorite records and accompany them while listening. i play chord after chord after chord and that doesn't work for every song, sure it's fine for some but it doesn't sound good for some. you know a lot about music and i guess you've gone through this sometime. how do i make my accompaniments more exciting, like get some interesting melodic or rythmic stuff going instead of playing chords on the right and octave root notes at the left.
045419.answer: it's tricky because when you're playing along to a record, there is already accompaniment there. so actually there's probably already too much if you are playing too. also if there is already a bass player, you need to not play root notes in the bass, unless you are entirely sure that you and the bass player will play exactly the same thing at exactly the same time. it will be helpful if you can get some kind of play-along recording which has your instrument muted

045482.question: 12.1.18 2:24 pm Someone asked about there being a 3/4 measure for half a bar in Christmas isn't Real and you said there was. 045508.question: I'm a self taught pianist and lately I've been wanting to start incorporating jazzy elements and melodies into my compositions. I have a pretty good grasp on music theory, but incorporating these elements is really hard for me. It always seems forced, even when utilizing 7ths and going off key with the help of the circle of fifths, I can't make it sound truly organic. I'd really appreciate some advic on how to do better.
045508.answer: you will need to pinpoint the source of your desire to do whatever it is you are trying to do. was there a certain song you heard that made you want to do things a certain way? if so, start by learning to do it exactly the way that song did. if it was simply just someone telling you about how they do things a certain way but you didn't actually hear it, then all you have to do is describe your own work to someone else in the same way and you probably don't even have to change the work itself

045546.question: Hey Bill, I know everyone and everything pressures and tries to HARD to get you to monetize. But I'm so glad that you don't. I get to find am your music in one place and download it all easily and with no charge. And I don't have any money so I usually have to illegally download music and feel guilty about it. Instead I get all your music free with no charge and no bad feelings. Your content makes me happy and inspired. 045574.question: Ok, prove to me that the plain old audio wouldn't work for reality

045578.question: You mentioned on the podcast that you've heard some believable ghost stories from people. Have you ever experienced anything metaphysical yourself? Maybe something you couldn't explain?
045578.answer: the best one i have is the shamrock light. i promise this is a boring story. it is a piece of st. patrick's day merchandice, very cheap, that has been hanging around since 2013. it is hanging very high, by the window (it can be seen near the S of the "hiring all positions" sign). it is a green bow tie, with a shamrock light. i guess if you squeeze it it starts blinking, but i didn't know that. so one day about 6 months ago it started blinking, without being touched for over 5 years. i climbed up to check it out, because i don't even know how the thing is supposed to work, i just hung it there and never used it, but upon further investigation you have to squeeze a switch to get the light to start blinking, or stop blinking. so it turned itself on after not being touched for 5 years. anyway i hope you like my story

These are companies like Instagram, Facebook, Whatsapp, Youtube etc that algorithmically feed content to entire societies, and/or keep them hooked using techniques that are known to be addictive. The whole IM thing too is a very unnatural way to speak to other people. I think all of this combined is disastrous for attention span, creativity, and normal social skills. 045945.question: Bill, I wanted to talk to you about something. I think that throughout my career as a musician I have contracted a virus that I can only identify as "bridge section fanatic syndrome" or something. It happens even with the classics, to me. Name an artist, I will likely be a fan of their bridges or "c sections" alone, even with their most classic songs. It happens with music from all eras (although lately I'm finding a lack in true bridge sections as an entity, if you will, specially in hip hop and trap, even though I enjoy a lot of the music). Those sections are NOTHING without the context of the song but somehow I find myself listening to the entire thing just to get there and enjoy them, justified in my enjoyment for having given that section it's moment to shine (not isolated) but preferring it to the rest of the track nonetheless. It's really weird and it just hit me, thinking about it. I find myself writing songs and instrumentals as strong as I can with the purpose of having the thrill of creating a bridge that I love, just for that piece of music. Does anything like this happen to you? Thanks for reading this convoluted text, I'm in the middle of a tornado of self discovery.

046003.question: Do you have any tips for someone looking to streamline their creative process? I've gotten into composition over the past year, and I think my concepts have a lot of potential, but I'm having trouble managing my time and turning the concepts into finished products. Also, I have trouble deciding when a product is finished, and when there's nothing left to be done on it.
046003.answer: it sounds like you need to do the 'small projects' trick. make very very small projects. you will learn everything you need to know about every stage of the process, because it will be much easier to move through them all, repeatedly. you will learn quickly this way. and if it's not working, make the projects even smaller, until it works

046226.question: Ok you're answering lots of equal temperament questions so I'll ask another heavily debated music question. What do you tune your A to? Do you take a particular stance in the 440Hz vs 432Hz debate, or is there somewhere else you go? Or do you simply not care?
046226.answer: just 1 it seems to me that's not heavily debated ..... 99% of today's music seems to be at a=440, because that's what all music programs are tuned to unless you crawl around in the settings 440 we are living in a time where there is more agreement about tuning than ever before. because everything's digital, and programs default to 440. most people are pitch correcting their vocals, and it would be 440. even just 30 years ago, things were all over the place because things were on tape, and the speed could get changed either deliberately or not. my decision to stay in tune with the rest of the world is actually mostly out of convenience for other musicians. it happens to be very convenient that almost everything is 440, because if you have an instrument in your hand you can play along with anything. and when that old tape tune comes on that's out of key, you basically can't play to it unless you feel like re-tuning. it may sound fresh to avoid 440, but it doesn't ultimately make a difference, and it is very convenient for all the players out there if i stay in 440

046363.question: if it's so important for you to have the exact date your content was created/finished on your website, rather than the date it was published, why do your song dates still show the same day as the videos? Clearly you have to finish them one or two days early for them to come out the same day as the videos. For example "just did a bad thing" came out today, 12/17 but you will probably list it as 12/18 in the song page. What gives?
046363.answer: almost everything in existence has a range of dates that are significant for it. for example, these questions have 2 dates/times that would be significant: the time you asked it, and the time i answered it. (actually this question seems to have 3 dates associated with it, because it appears to be copied from a question composed around 12/17) but for simplicity's sake i must choose 1 date which i think is most appropriate, based on the type of content it is. showing 2 or more dates for 1 thing is just too many numbers to take in, and does not appear clear at all. so depending on what type of content it is, the date which i feel best represents that piece of content may be derived a different way. the making of this website has been an ongoing attempt to organize things as clearly as i can, but again and again the reality will defy the categorization system in subtle ways. but i can hardly complain about that because that's just something our world loves to do. also the song was released on 12/18 not 12/17. but with advanced technology it may have been transmitted to you from a more easterly time zone which may have reached 12/18 sooner than you

046396.question: 12.20.18 7:55 pm sorry for the confusion. here's my question: isn't it innacurate to call B E F A Bmin7 (b5) since that chord symbol doesn't account for the 11 in the chord? would something like Bmin7 (11b5) be more accurate? also, is it typical to hear both a natural extension and the augmented extension of the same note in the same voicing (like how this chord contains both the 11 and the #11)? thanks
046396.answer: yea, it's iffy. Bmin7b5 kind of suggests you'd have D instead of E. but the specific notes you mentioned don't have an easy happy looking chord symbol. like Fmaj7b5/B would be the best i could do, and precise, but still obnoxious to read decent i guess. but whoever reads that will probably put a D in so be ready for that if you write that for someone at some point i think there is a sort of matrix that falls away and you realize that the way you are using the word 'extension' really means nothing. it may be an extension in terms of which year you may learn it in school. but in the real world i can't think of any reason to say which note of a chord should be considered an 'extension.' i think it will throw you way off to think of it that way. but as far as using E and F in the same chord, try it and see. the chord you gave seems weird but in context it could be fine. don't forget to play it in the song and not out of the song

046403.question: So I like playing by ear and I like reading music, and have been getting better at both of those, and I want to get better at arranging and composing too, but whenever I try I end up wanting to do anything else. I want to be able to do it all on my own, but it seems like I'm not getting anywhere, I've tried pencil and paper, as well as musescore, but neither helped, nor does starting simple. Any advise? Do I have to get locked in a room with nothing to do but arrange music?
046403.answer: creating your own brand new music might be a more insane and fruitfully bizarre and unlimitedly powerful task than you may have expected. it's really really powerful stuff, it's kind of like staring directly into the big bang. at least that's the way it feels for me. it can be diffucult to swallow, at first. and treating it like anything 'normal' seems to fall flat most of the time. try to experiment a little more loosely for a while, and have fun completely disobeying the assignment. like at least for the first few tries try instead of writing a song try writing a boomerang. or something. songwriting is really really crazy and there is a ridiculous amount of power you can have, and responsibility, ..... i mean like freedom. i mean like, you are litterally making the whole thing up. so don't underestimate how insane of a task that is. and just put on your overalls and jump in. it's weird but it's the most fulfilling ride of a lifetime

046515.question: Hey Bill, recently I've been thinking a lot about how augmented chords and how sad it is that they're almost never used. Do you know why that is? What are some cool ways that an aug chord could be used, perhaps an example from some music you like or have written?
046515.answer: i think it's an illusion, based on the fact that it has been taught to you in the same context as major and minor chords. but it's really not that. it's actually 1 of many variety of whole tone based chordal situations. which are not happy nor sad but kind of tense feeling. and they are best used as transitions, usually, .... and the one particular arrangement that may have been taught to you as an 'augmented' chord (the augmented triad) is just 1 of many ways to use that stuff if you get in a time machine and go to the late 70s and check out some minor key r&b songs, i think you may find that the 5 chord will be something like this: say it's the key of C minor, you're gonna see something called Gaug7 which has G in the bass and then it has F, B, and Eb in the chord. but this is not quite the thing you are talking about, although it is more common than the thing you are talking about. and it is still used today not just in the 70s

046517.question: 11.29.18 11:09 am If you think it would be fun, would you care to explain long long long journey?
046517.answer: came up with the chorus first. then i had to find verses. actually found the verse melody before any lyrics. knowing the chorus but not knowing the verse that starts the song is a very strange mystery to solve sometimes. writing forwards you can just ask what comes next. but figuring out what came before (writing backwards) is really strange. but after finding the verse melody, i started searching for lyrics, and 'remember' seemed to work best. 'i wonder if you remember' ... 'i remember the morning ...' 'do you remember the morning you said that it's over' ... i'm just reading what i wrote down in that writing session. these were all brainstormed lines for the first verse before i found the real thing. 'i wonder if you remember the place that we came from' . none of these are good enough .... ' i remember the first time i said something intelligent' ... 'i remember the moment i left where i came from ' ... 'i remember the first thing i said when i got here' ... There are some slightly more interesting ones but i can't tell you them. 'i'm slipping under the blanket where nobody sees me' i don't know if that was supposed to be for the first line or for another line but it fits the same melody. i can see the post card lyric floating around here. actually took quite a bit of brainstorming before the actual first line came to me (moment that my dreams were broken) and i very distinctively knew that had to be it. and then from there it's just coming up with lines are good enough. keep coming up with lines until one of them seems good enough. then keep going. etc. that's about all there is to it. and if you don't have a deadline you will never think anything is good enough, and if you have a deadline you still won't think it's good enough but that will force you to come up with something that is almost good enough maybe

046536.question: i must say that i think the "i just did a bad thing" videos is one of your strongest visual offerings. i listened to the song a *lot* in the week between when it came out and when the music video came out, and the video still managed to add to the thoughts the song generates in my brain. it was totally worth the extra week to make it the way that it ended up being. Would you consider making the schedule more flexible to accommodate the extra time that ends up needing to go into certain things? You've mentioned things like releasing songs/videos on every other tuesday and anything videos on the other tuesday, but I would support a more low-key thing where the deadline was that you had to release *something* every tuesday, but depending on what ended up getting finished, it could either be a song, music video, and 30-second anything video, or just a 5-second anything video.
046536.answer: no, the extra time this time was not spent making anything better. it was spent in an absolute state of panic and meltdown. and i am not confident that the product was any better as a result, in fact i am quite sure it was weaker tried that from january 31, 2018, and it became instantly clear that songs would be impossible in this time frame. it would have been all non-song videos if i had continued with that 'we'll see' approach can't leave it up to 'what ends up getting finished'. then it will never get finished. trust me, i've been through this many many times before i'm not disrupting the 2 weeks song schedule. it's the best thing that ever happened to me, and in the last month i've been a complete mental and emotional meltdown as a direct result of its temporary failure

046555.question: Have you ever tried to write melodies and lyrics after you've written the instrumental? This is the order in which I write lately and it can be a fun challenge to make it all fit
046555.answer: that's true, there are many different ways to write and almost all of them present new and fun challenges. i've tried it that way and it is fun, but, i've generally come to the conclusion that it is usually not the best way to exploit my specific strengths. and it's also been a very common/popular way for people to write in the last 10 years or so (instrumental first, then everything else). given the fact that i am capable of bending the music at the will of the melody/lyric (it's easy and fun for me to do that), i have generally determined that it is best to embrace and exploit this to the fullest, as a cutting edge advantage over my opponents in the times i am living in

046855.question: there's a thing that comes up among people who are self taught with music or whatever people who do that are said to have "gaps in their knowledge"-stuff people with more formal education learned in school about proper technique or whatever. i always think that's a little strange to say because everybody has gaps in their knowledge, just the people who studied in school have all filled the same gaps. how do you recommend self taught musicians (like me) fill in those gaps? i kinda think if you pay enough attention to how other people do it, and you are somehow very relaxed yet focused, you can pretty much do whatever
046855.answer: really it's just like learning to read. the words don't change if you can't read, but reading/writing will help you communicate with the wider world. i'd say just get some song books. learn to read them. now that the internet is a thing, you can pretty much just look up everything you need to know 1 by 1. but i think song books would be the best thing, not only to become literate but it will probably introduce you to more songs and make you a stronger musical person in general

046859.question: Out of curiosity I slowed down Mount St. Helens to listen more closely to the rhythm of the vocals during the parts where it sounds like you're singing too many syllables over one beat (e.g. "and it's gonna be a" on beat 4 of measure 1). What it seems like you are consistently doing is having three accents during the beat ("AND it's GONna BE a"), but when I listened more closely you aren't doing a triplet feel over the beat, but rather, depending on the words in each particular occurrence, a 3-3-2, 3-2-3, or 2-3-3 pattern of 32nd notes (which fits better with the 16th note rhythms in the instruments than a triplet would). My question is: are you intentionally writing the melody with 32nd note syncopation like that? Or are you just thinking about doing 3 accents over the beat? Either way, I'm impressed. Either you're successfully performing a near-impossible rhythm that you've written, or you're naturally creating one by ear as you try to sing with the best feel you can.
046859.answer: generally i'd say if you are hearing it differently as a result of slowing it down, that's probably not the way i was thinking it. i was writing it according to the speed it is on normal play mode

046932.question: BILL I JUST SAW AN AD ON YOUR BALL & STICK VIDEO ARE YOU INSANE
046932.answer: no, what happened is i finally realized once and for all that youtube is now recommending videos much more if they have stronger monetization. i have heard rumors that they would start doing this and knew they would eventually, but i proved it very clearly recently. because the ball and stick video was listed as #2 on trending when you click into the trending list, but, it was not showing up in recommendations where top 5 trending videos are supposed to show up. i did a test on a clean cookie-free (identity-free) browser, and went to youtube.com. on the front page of youtube, the top row of 5 videos is recommended trending videos. if you keep refreshing it, it seems to display mostly videos from the top 8 or so, switching around slightly with each refresh but usually mostly the same videos, all taken from the top of the trending list. but i refreshed it several times and mine was simply never there, despite being listed as #2 on the actual trending list. so i did an experiment and turned on 5 sec skippables for that video, and it instantly started appearing on the front page every time. so essentially this proves to me that the youtube algorhythm is strongly favoring videos with better monetization, which i always suspected would eventually be true. so essentially i can no longer trust youtube to give my videos a fair shake if they have the weakest monetization settings (i.e. display ads only). the good news is, i still offer all my content downloadable for free on billwurtz dot com, so they can be played in an offline video player of your choosing, which for me personally is the way i strongly prefer to watch content anyway. in fact i never even wanted to join youtube because i can't stand watching videos in an online streaming player. much prefer to download. but i gotta get the stuff on as many sites as possible, and play by their rules if necessary. after all that's probably how most of you found me

046937.question: There's a song where one bar of the verse sounds like it's in 4/4 time and the next bar sounds like it's in 3/4 so it sounds like the verse just alternates between 4/4 and 3/4 but I wanted to know what time signature this is since I assume it doesn't just constantly switch back and forth (for clarification it goes 1 2 3 4 | 1 2 3 | 1 2 3 4 |)
046937.answer: whoever writes it down gets to decide. it depends which way you think is easier to read. you can say 7/4 if you don't mind your bars being huge. you can make the bars reasonable size if you don't mind writing 4/4 then 3/4 etc. at the beginning of every bar. or, what i've actually seen, is you can write something like 4/4 + 3/4, at the beginning. and that means that it alternates. that's probably what i might do. OR, another option is to use 7/4 and put a dotted bar line in the middle of each bar to split it up the way you counted it

047009.question: what's the difference between A6 and A13?
047009.answer: A13 has G in it. it's just a weird quirk of society, that A13 means A7 with 13, and A7 is short for A dominant 7, which means it has b7 in it. A6 is not a dominant 7 chord. and don't ask me what dominant means, it just means it includes b7. it is not dominating anything in any way. except actually it probably dominated the blues scene so hard that it was the only chord anyone ever used so they stopped saying dominant and A7 became the default shorthand for A dominant 7

047089.question: why is a f# commonly called f# but a eb is commonly called eb. why can't they make up their minds
047089.answer: the key of Eb is much more famous than the key of D# because the key of Eb has only 3 flats and the key of D# has 9. and the note F# is more famous than the note Gb because you start getting F#s right away in the sharp key signatures (it's in all of them) and yet with flat key signatures you don't get the Gb note until you have 5 flats or more

047114.question: So you seem like someone who is talented when it comes to making yourself get work done. So, I was wondering if I could like pitch you an idea that I thought of trying for myself to start making more music, and see if you had any feedback? idk. The plan would be for me to spend, for each song, three days on the melody, then three days on the harmony, then three days on the percussion, then three days on the bassline, and finish with two days to revise and edit. Do you think this is a good plan? Anyway, love everything you do! Keep it up! <3
047114.answer: that method seems very strange to me, but it might work, if you are not used to coming up with everything all at the same time. my approach to the over-whelm of not knowing what to do would be to just simply make much much much much much shorter products. and if it still doesn't work try making it shorter. a good example of the first one i did on this strategy was "die", literally only syllable. 1 word, 1 syllable, 1 melody note, 1 chord, 1 bass note, 1 kick drum, etc.... conceived of quite instantly, and recorded very quickly, because it was very clear what to do. that one was supposed to be 1 second, so the next one can be 2 seconds, except i discovered that the ringing crash cymbal made it 2 seconds so i actually went shorter first and did one that was truly 1 second, which was 'bears', before moving onto 2 seconds

047119.question: When I want to change keys, I have the choice between 11 different keys. How do I know which key I want to change into?
047119.answer: don't worry about that. simply listen to the song all up to its current point, and imagine what you want the next part to sound like. then find out what those notes and chords were. then the analysts (maybe you, maybe someone else, ...) can try to figure out what key they went to. sometimes people may even disagree on what key it was, because when you change keys you have opened the door to change, and sometimes you may be roaming the hallways instead of going explicitly into 1 room. or in some cases you may have entered a room but through the side door, which can cause potential disagreements about which key it was. but it still sounds the way it sounds so just pay attention to what sound you want. unless you are making music primarily for a wall decoration, in which case you should use B# major, to wow your guests

047120.question: should i follow my brain telling me music isn't right for me and that i'll suck at it and that it's too confusing for me and i'll never be good at it and never learn how to do music good etc etc or should i listen to this intense feeling i have in my gut (that i get when listening to music sometimes) that is saying I DESPERATELY WANT TO LEARN HOW TO PLAY INSTRUMENTS AND MAKE GOOD MUSIC!!!!! it keeps coming back around to me ... the want to be able to make and play music stuff, but .. i keep getting discouraged, because music seems so complicated and all these weird names for these 2985395359835 million chords and note combinations OR WHATEVER YOU CALL THEM keep making me want to rip off my face because i know i'll never be able to understand it all WHAT DO I DO. DO I LISTEN TO MY DISCOURAGEMENT OR DO I LISTEN TO THE MAJOR WANT TO BE ABLE TO DO MUSIC BY THE WAY I HOPE THIS ALL MADE SENSE THANK YOU
047120.answer: just remember the golden rule. music is everywhere and anywhere. it is assembled through small small bits and pieces. try tapping everything around, and see what sounds they make. this should already be fun. if you are in the city, start tapping sign posts. i think you will be pretty thrilled at the different sounds they all make

047182.question: How did the 'La de da de da de da de day oh' song come to be? It sounds so good to me! It probably was similar to the process of other songs, but I'm asking because, in my opinion, it really stands out, and I want to know more about it. Also, keep up the good work, I think 'Just did a bad thing' may be your best song yet.
047182.answer: this may sound boring and technical but i wrote some of it on a writing session, then wrote a bit more of it on a writing session, and then finally wrote the remainder of the song during a writing session. that's the short story. the long story is, i was doing a writing session many many years ago after many years of not doing writing sessions. actually it felt like i had never done a writing session before, it had been so long. i know i did many years before that, but it seemed so far away and i'm not quite sure how i ever did it. too long ago to remember really, and the world had surely changed since then, mine and everyone else's. so i was doing something which i think might have been totally new, i was just writing. not in the recording thing, not trying to record and write at the same time, just writing. like on paper, and i had 1 instrument to play along to what i was singing, and weirdly it was an unplugged bass. which doesn't quite make sense but it was a quiet room and i was just using it to indicate chords. not play chords, but just play the bass notes to indicate chords. so a few things were written on that session, including a thing that looked like this. you may mostly recognize this verse, sort of mostly. but the chorus it goes to on this page (not shown) is completely different, and wraps up to a surprise twist ending very quickly, making it a probably less than 1 minute piece called, presumably, 'in the snow.' the snow not really being the chorus, the snow being the twist ending. so that's 'in the snow.' fast forward maybe 3 and a half years. i am getting my life togther and going through the stacks and stacks of writing sessions i've done over the years, and getting it all organized and doing writing on them, for days and days and days and days and weeks, a many months long writing-only period i call 'writing tare' when i worked only on writing for almost a year, and not starting any new ones, just updating/continuing/finishing/fixing on existing songs and fragments. very early on in this process, around september 2012, i took a look at 'in the snow,' made some small adjustments to the verse to make it stronger, the pre-chorus got changed from 'i'm gonna count to 3' to instead 'i'm gonna write a song'. therefore the old chorus didn't make sense (something about counting to 3 i assume) ditched it and wrote a brand new much brighter stronger chorus, which as you can see seems to be nearly exactly the la de da chorus. and then it sat there burning a hole in my shelf, as a ray of sunshine with a high standard i suppose i was afraid to live up to. fast forward to 2017, i've been actually recording songs, and videos of many different types, for many years at this point, and over the years the writing list had grown out of control, mostly from 2010 to 2013 but still even more later, so most of the time doing a song (recording + video) means going through the list and finding something i want to do. in post-hotewig i had made the decision to allow fragments to be picked (songs where only partial writing was done) so as to get something almost entirely new and finish the writing on the spot and record it. out of something like 400 to choose from, i manually got it down to about 41 finalists, planning to do a random number selection to choose. but i narrowed it down again manually to 27, and with agonizing fear i chose the number and it picked la de da. and then the next day i had terrible cold feet about it, thought it was lame and stupid. switched it to a slow song, switched it to another song, lost my mind, wasn't sure, and then somewhere around getting into the haircut chair (was planning on doing real video performance footage for this one) i was pondering a second verse after the bright la de da chorus, and the first 3 mall lines tumbled into my head quite readily. so at least that mostly solidified the song choice for me and gave it an extra push toward validity, and from there the decision was finalized and i quickly finished the writing and then went into production which took agonizingly long because it turns out going on camera in front of zillions of people can be scary if you haven't been doing it regularly that is nice of you

047191.question: okay, so, this is long but hear me out. i live in super-serious college land with super-serious computer science people and i'm stuck here until summer, and then for the next 2 years (i'm already too deep to quit now). over the last three years or so i have been too afraid of being free. i live in this bubble where i pretend to be someone i'm not, even to the point where i'll just randomly want to burst out singing in public because i know it would cheer everyone up. i'm really a music and fitness guy who didn't have the balls to just try being a freelance musician, so i just relied on college. But now, i've realized college doesn't help me learn anything and also college sucks and i hate it.So basically, i'm a 5-year-old trapped in a young adult's body. i know that once i start being myself and fully commit to it, there will be no turning back to the old way of thinking, and i'm honestly completely okay with that, except i'm naturally a more "out-there" person than most people and many people i know, (including professors) can and have seen my assertiveness and certainty as disrespect or rudeness. I've requested a solo room so i can be a weirdo and make content in there without anyone judging me, so that's at least a start i guess. Point is, i'm going to change eventually, but the question is just time. My gut is telling me to break out of this mentality now, the sooner the better. I guess the question is, in your experience, is it beneficial to your insecurity around other people to start being yourself fully around them, or does just being yourself in front of a camera to the internet have the same effect? Basically i'm scared that if i just wait to become popular someday before i translate the skills to the real world, i'll just be even more hopelessly awkward when and if that time comes. i would love to just push myself to start now, but it's becoming increasingly clear that the only viable option is to ask for at least a tiny amount of validation from someone else before plunging headfirst into life-changing behavior. Any thoughts on this? Also how do you ask a follow-up question
047191.answer: yes very different. much much more calculated it's quite simple, it just comes from actual experience. if you find yourself on stage regularly, you will inevitably get totally used to it and very strong there. if you find yourself around people constantly, you will very quickly get much better and stronger. a nice trick is to get a job, any kind of job, where you are around people. i think you will learn a lot about the world regardless of what kind of job it is. and just when you least expect it you will notice that you got some money somehow which you could use to buy some flashy new socks, and matching sandals what the heck is a follow up question

047192.question: Why did you make the Burger King song like what was the purpose
047192.answer: that was a sort of insecurity defense mechanism. i was feeling hopeless, jobless, didn't really know how i was gonna get it together. was envious of people who had serious full time music biz careers, such as (for example) writing custom jingle songs for commercials! this is actually mostly a thing of the past, but i was fantasizing i guess. and i was hungry for burger king, but when you don't have a job you simply just can't just simply go out a spend money on burger king. so some kind of dillusional logic in my mind told me that if i could write and record a 30 second jingle for burger king, on the spot, that would at least justify going there somehow. so i did it. unfortunately the cutoff was not professional in the slightest, the damn thing ran way over, to like 34 maybe? but at least it got finished successfully, during a time when i was mostly way too confused to even exceed 5 seconds! so sure enough i did the 30+ burger king one and promptly went to actual burger king, which for the folks at home would be the one near astoria boulevard next to the N train

047205.question: I have a weird situation. About four years ago I finally stepped into making and singing music after growing up in an family that believed music making, esp singing, is the realm of an elite few talented people. I always rebelled against this idea in my heart because but didn't participate in misic making until I left that environment about 4 yrs ago. anyways, after 4 years of singing w a vocal group I could just feel that my voice, my ears, improv and other abilities had become quite strong. About 6 mo ago I leveled up again in my understanding of music and began making/recording my own music and performing more on my own time, not just with my group. So, I know my strongest suit is harmony and singing with others, but recently at a mic night I sang a song (used a mic) by myself, no accompanymnent, which is a first for me. Icould hear myself during and it I was delighted that my voice both sounded and felt good, which i have learned are some of several markers that you are making a good, strong sound. But a friend recorded it, then sent it to me later. I watched it to see what it sojnded like from an audiences persective and it actually didn't sound great, not bad but not good. There were a few notes I thought I nailed but were actually a little shaky, and overall tone was not as strong as I had felt it was in the moment. This devastates me because my body and my ears to ears told me it sounded nice while I was performing, but the actual recorded audio denies this...I feel shattered. So now I am wondering if I should just halt all my musical persuits, if I still apparently am not a strong singer even after lots of practice over the last few years and a sense that I had grown into my own voice. I love making music more than anything, and my favorite instrument is voices because it feels so physial and raw to share music that way. but if my soundmaker is fundamentally gross than I feel the whole process is perverted from the get-go. So i'm looking for guidance from friends and musicians I trust: is there anything here that i mentioned you are familiar with and have advice for? and is it a good idea to trust that wonderful sensation inside you when you are singing that tells you the sound is pleasing? and thanks for fielding this long ask
047205.answer: no i am familiar with doing something for a while and then getting to the point where you really feel like you are getting good. then doing it more and then really feeling like you are getting even better. you explained that part very clearly, and it's obviously true yes, that's the only thing there is don't forget to do more live appearances, as many as you can. and if you think there is a problem with the recorded result not being as good as you thought, then keep doing that too. you can learn that just the same as you learned all the other stuff you've learned. also don't forget, ............ singing without any chordal accompaniment is probably gonna be really really strange, unless you are singing music that was absolutely not written with chords

047244.question: "Just did a bad thing" is the most addictive piece of music ive ever heard. it's structured so perfectly. what happened that made you come up with that song? i suppose my question is... what bad thing did you do, Bill Wurtz?
047244.answer: nothing really, that first line is just one of many other song ideas from a song idea generating session. not even the best one, probably one of the worst actually. but the reason it got picked for recording was due to time constraints. i kept narrowing it down and ended up excluding all the choices for not being good enough until i narrowed it down to 1 but then i excluded that one too for not being good enough. 'bad thing' was excluded way earlier, because it was one of the least good. so after having eventually excluding them all for not being good enough, i realized i was at a dead end and the clock was running out so for a twist i just kind of picked one of the worst ones, and wrote it extremely quickly. this was actually an advantage, because when you try to make a bad thing good in a very short amount of time, you are forced to bring out your very best. it's kind of like when it's 8:59 and the bread store is closing at 9:00, you will discover some automobile maneuvering skills you perhaps didn't know you had, just to get that bread the ones i've done i usually put my name on

047257.question: 1.11.19 2:46 pm - Your answer sounds romantic but that's not the case. Most pop songs use the same I-V-vi-IV chord progression - there has to be something about this that is objectively more pleasing than other chord combinations to the human ear, else the same formula wouldn't work again and again as it does now to make hits. The number of combinations that achieve the same effect must be limited and there has to be a pattern to it. Isn't that what studying music is all about?
047257.answer: yes it is actually more songs use 4, 6-, 1, 5 (same thing but different order) at least from about 1990-2015, but that trend may be starting to fade. for a long time the blues was most popular. but still these have never actually amounted to 'most music.' a 'plurality' possibly but not a 'majority' sorry for the statistics terminology yes but don't forget to put lyrics and melodies in too, or at least something besides just the chords, otherwise you might not have too much going for you

047427.question: Bill I have to tell you, I used to view your music in a meme way when I was less mature and it was all only for laughs. Didyl you have an "a-ha" moment where you started taking it more seriously or were you always pretty serious about your music?

I do understand it's common for everyone that do things to experience defeats and get a bit depressed on their way to victory, but some people just build up this mood very slowly or it can be easily eclipsed by something else, which marks a sharp difference with my own case-overwhelmed and giving up too quickly before I can strike the sweetpoint. 047700.question: OK bill, I need you to please please please help me out on this one: I have watched your interview with H3H3 I don't know how many times (too many), 'cause say what you want, but I think it's reeeally good. The part that I can't stop going back to over and over is when you talk about schedules, which are absolutely crucial for *getting things done*. Without them I've also noticed that there are just so many options, and you end up being all over the place, and one thing can go on forever. Now, I'm pretty darn good at planning and making schedules, but where I mess up is in the execution. I can't stick to my plans mainly because I get distracted. As soon as whatever was planned on the schedule starts getting a bit difficult, or uncomfortable, I stop doing it and switch to a non-planned activity such as reading the news on twitter, or some other lame thing like that. Now don't get me wrong, I really want to do the thing s that I 've planned and are on the schedule, I like those things and I feel enthusiastic about it, it's just that whenever it gets hard, I'm too weak. What's the secret to stick to the schedule no. matter. what.? I don't want to get old and be like: "arghasdh... I was meant to do all those good things, but I was way too weak to end them D: ...I hate myself! "

047715.question: hey bill, it's the dom9no3 chord guy whose question you didn't follow when I initially asked it. This is what I was getting at (more fleshed out). The dom9 chord (e.g. G9: G-B-D-F-A) is probably the most consonant combination of 5 notes that we have in the 12-note scale. In lots of compositions, chords are more frequently thought of in 4 voices instead of 5 (thank u bach chorales), so we frequently encounter chords that are 4 out of the 5 notes of a dominant 9 chord. Using the G chord, we have G7 = G9 no9, Gadd9 = G9 no7, Dm6 = B hdim7 = G9 no1, and I sometimes also see G9 approximated in 4 voices by leaving out the 5th. These four are all pretty common chords, all quite consonant. But the 5th 4-pitch chord coming from the dom9 that should be just as consonant as the other 4 is G9 no3 = {D,F,G,A} = d minor add4. The frequency I see minor add4 chords in leadsheets and such is basically zero compared to the other 4 chords that are dom9 chords omitting 1 of the 5 notes. Do you feel there is a good reason for this? Is the the minor add4 chord lacking something musically that makes it rare compared to the other chords mentioned, even though it should ""theoretically"" sound just as reasonable?
047715.answer: consonant? not sure what that means here i'd call it Dmin over G, which is rampantly common, especially in the 1970s 'funk' sort of things. it can be used in the place of G9 or Gmin9. you wouldn't have to specify. james brown songs use these all day. i use them all the time if you put the bass on G, which i think is where it's supposed to be according to your study, i think you will find it much more commonly. or actually perhaps the lead sheet will just say G9 or Gmin9 but in reality the execution will leave out the 3rd this study is not really taking account for where the bass is i'm not following why it 'should theoretically' sound just as reasonable, but if you feel it has been under-used, you now have an opportunity to find and demonstrate its goodness. if you find that it really is not so good, then it is only you who can explain why you don't like it

047904.question: Hey, i'm just now learning about intervals and harmonies and stuff and i've been listening to this song and it just confused me. (https://youtu.be/GC6nSX67Q-4?t=31 i linked to the relevant part at 31 sec). Listen to the guitar melody, it has these notes in it, ignoring all the little thrills and slides, - F# B A C#. And then the second guitar comes in and harmonizes over the first and I figured out that the harmony is a minor third (correct me if im wrong). But here's the confusion: the notes in the harmony are A D C# E, and A D E are all a minor third of the corresponding notes in guitar 1 - F# B C#. BUT the C# in guitar 2 is a MAJOR THIRD away from the A in guitar 1. And it sounds bloody cool. What's going on here, why isn't that C# a C, and why does changing that one note make it sound so much better?
047904.answer: let's skip the harmony and just look at melodies. in most songs, they don't use all the notes. they tend to use some, but kind of skip the ones in between. typically if you lay out all 12 notes in order, xxxxxxxxxxxx, an ordinary song for example usually is only gonna use these notes 0x0x00x0x0x0. you'll notice that's uneven. and if you're wondering what happens when it's completely evenly distributed: 0x0x0x0x0x0x, well you'll notice it sounds like you are spinning around. i've still left most of life's most important questions unanswered, but hopefully this is a more direct way of accessing the conundrum you mentioned, which has nothing to do with harmony

047926.question: hi bill, it's the same person asking about the harmonies and intervals of that melody and i've been experimenting some more and i found another strange thing. I tried some different harmonies over that melody i already mentioned (with notes F# B A C#) and I found that D G F# A over that melody also works in a cool way? How come when G isn't in the A major scale at all (i think G is a diminished 7 in that scale, correct me if im wrong)? Is there any rhyme or reason of why some things apparently work and some don't? Like some broken rules get you an even cooler thing but if you break some other rule it gets you a bad thing? Or is my knowledge of the rules so bad that i'm not actually breaking any just discovering new rules i didnt even know about?
047926.answer: yea that would be almost like you are in the key of D it's in what you might call the A "cool" major scale, the ancient greek name for that being "mixolydian." which also happens to be the exact same notes as the regular key of D, if you rotate the room around flat7 scientists will never quite figure it out but they will keep trying it is essentially the same rules that make you like someone's personality, or enjoy a story, or find beauty in patterns of soap scum

048042.question: 1.27.19 8:04 pm what is your set up for this? how can i do that
048042.answer: you can do it with your phone, but i use a smaller device called a 'digital voice recorder.' i can't say what brand it is but i've been using the same one since 2010 (and before that i was using a similar one.) if you search for digital voice recorders i think you will find the kind of device i am talking about. i've discovered the best thing is to put it in the small pocket on the sun visor. then i discovered that this actually vibrates sometimes, (unfortunately most recordings i have from 2015 have a lot of vibrations in them) but after doing the journal edits project (making the reality page) in 2016 i discovered that i could use a glove to cushion the recorder, and also place a folded sock between the visor and the ceiling. this fixed the problem. that was in my previous car, and my current car, the pocket was actually too tight to hold the voice recorder but after stretching it out a bit now it fits. and i don't think there are any vibration problems but who knows, maybe there are, and i will discover it when i do the next round of reality edits

048056.question: How do you remember stuff about the music you listen to? I'm asking specifically about your answers to the questions "what are some songs with only 2 chords" and "with only 1 chord".
